questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of shock:
questions.solution:
Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock and to some degree is a component of all other types of shock.

Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

Shock can be classified as follows:

Shock Inciting mechanism
Hypovolemic shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

(eg., hemorrhage, dehydration)
Cardiogenic shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

(eg., myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias)
Obstructive shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling 

(eg., cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)
Distributive shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

(eg., anaphylaxis due to histamine release, sepsis due to the release of bacterial products, spinal cord injury due to sympathetic failure)
Endocrine shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic or distributive shock.

(eg., hypo and hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency)

questions.text: A patient is treated for hypovolemic shock following a motor vehicle collision. Which of the following is not a compensatory mechanism that is anticipated to occur in this patient?

choices.text: Reduced perfusion to the GI tract

questions.solution:
The compensatory mechanism in shock reduces the perfusion to the skin, muscle and gastrointestinal tract and not to the kidney.

As shock progresses, the body’s cardiovascular and endocrine compensatory responses reduce the blood flow to non-essential organs by vasoconstriction. This occurs in order to preserve preload and flow to the kidneys, lungs and brain.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, he had multiple injuries over his body and was found to be in class II hemorrhagic shock. The percentage of blood loss would be between:
questions.solution:
The percentage of blood loss in class II hemorrhagic shock is 15–30%, which amounts to a loss of 750–1500 mL of blood.

The class II hemorrhagic shock is considered as a mild shock with heart rate more than 100. It is associated with orthostatic hypotension, and the patient is usually anxious at this stage.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 23-year-old man presents with breathlessness. On examination, he has hypotension and distended neck veins. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds are heard. What is this condition primarily associated with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of Beck's triad (hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds) is seen in cardiac tamponade. Shock due to cardiac tamponade is primarily an example of obstructive shock.

Obstructive shock is characterized by a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling of the left and/or right sides of the heart, which in turn leads to fall in cardiac output. Common causes of obstructive shock include:

  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Massive pulmonary embolus or air embolus

Cardiogenic shock is due to primary failure of the heart to pump blood. It may be due to myocardial depression as a result of infarction, cardiomyopathy, blunt myocardial injury. Patients with cardiac tamponade may eventually develop cardiogenic shock as the myocardium is stressed against the obstruction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustained a spinal cord injury as a result of a road traffic accident. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. All of the following findings can be seen in the patient except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the presence of hypotension associated with the spinal cord injury is suggestive of neurogenic shock. It is associated with bradycardia and not tachycardia.

Neurogenic shock refers to reduced tissue perfusion due to loss of vasomotor tone to peripheral arterial beds.

Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic regulation of peripheral vascular tone. Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in increased vascular capacitance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output.

The classic description of neurogenic shock consists of:

  • Hypotension associated with bradycardia (absence of reflexive tachycardia due to disrupted sympathetic discharge)
  • Warm extremities (due to loss of peripheral vasoconstriction)
  • Motor and sensory deficits indicative of a spinal cord injury
  • Radiographic evidence of a vertebral column fracture

questions.text:
Modified shock index is calculated using?

HR: Heart rate

MAP: Mean arterial pressure

SBP: Systolic blood pressure

DBP: Diastolic blood pressure
questions.solution:
• Modified shock index = HR/MAP 
  • Original shock index = HR/SBP 

The shock index is a hemodynamic stability indicator. In patients with shock, it is a better predictor of mortality than blood pressure or heart rate alone. A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

The modified shock index is a more sensitive indicator of tissue perfusion than the original shock index. In critically ill patients, the DBP decreases earlier than SBP, hence, the modified shock index using MAP is better suited to assess the severity of shock.

questions.text: The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in ____________
questions.solution:
The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in distributive shock.

It is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. The most common cause of distributive shock is sepsis.

The causes of vasodilatation in various types of distributive shock:

Type of distributive shock  Cause of vasodilatation 
Septic shock  Release of bacterial products (endotoxin) and the activation of cellular and humoral components of the immune system. 
Anaphylactic shock  Histamine release 
Neurogenic shock (spinal cord injury)  Failure of sympathetic outflow and adequate vascular tone 

The following Table shows cardiovascular and metabolic characteristics of different types of shock.

  Hypovolemia Cardiogenic Obstructive Distributive
Cardiac output Low Low Low

High (in septic and anaphylactic shock)

Low (in neurogenic shock)
Vascular resistance High High High Low
Venous pressure Low High High Low
Mixed venous saturation Low Low Low High
Base deficit High High High High

questions.text: A patient who was admitted with third-degree burns presents with light-headedness and oliguria on the third day of admission. On examination, the peripheries are warm and capillary refill is brisk. His pulse rate is 138/min. In which of the following types of shock do you see this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is seen in septic shock.

In distributive (septic) shock, the peripheries are warm and capillary refill will be brisk, despite the profound shock.

In early stages (compensated stage) of septic shock, the patient has clammy, warm peripheries. The latter is a distinct feature from other types of shock where peripheral vasoconstriction leads to cold peripheries. The patient will have decreased vascular resistance, inadequate afterload, abnormally high cardiac output, and tachycardia.

In the later stages (uncompensated phase) of septic shock, there is reduced venous return, preload, and reduced cardiac output with low blood pressure.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man with a history of recurrent urinary tract infection presents with fever, tachypnea, and tachycardia. On examination, he appears confused and has hypotension. Which of the following is used as the initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock. Crystalloids are the initial fluid of choice in the resuscitation of severe sepsis and septic shock.

Septic shock is also known as vasodilatory shock (But remember vasopressors are not the first line).

Management protocol for septic shock:

Step 1: Immediate evaluation - Securing the airway (if indicated) and correcting hypoxemia and establishing venous access for the early administration of fluids and antibiotics are priorities in the management of patients with sepsis and septic shock.

Step 2: Initial resuscitative therapy - aggressive administration of intravenous fluids (IVF), usually crystalloids are given at 30 mL/kg (actual body weight) within the first three hours following the presentation. Empirical antibiotic therapy started within first hour.

Step 3: Intravenous vasopressors are useful in patients who remain hypotensive despite adequate fluid resuscitation or who develop cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

Vasopressor agents such as phenylephrine, noradrenaline are indicated in distributive shock states which include septic shock, neurogenic shock, etc. where there is peripheral vasodilatation, and a low systemic vascular resistance, leading to hypotension. But they are not the first-line treatment.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at the blood bank and receive several units of packed RBCs, platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate following a blood donation camp. Which among the following components would you want to use at the earliest?
questions.solution:
Platelets have a shelf life of only 5 days and hence they have to be used at the earliest.

They are usually stored on a special agitator at 20–24 °C. They are given to the patients with thrombocytopenia or with platelet dysfunction who are bleeding or undergoing surgery.

Packed cells (PRBCs) are stored in a SAG-M solution (saline–adenine–glucose–mannitol) and has a shelf life of 42 days at 2–6 °C. (Older storage regimens included storage in CPD – citrate–phosphate–dextrose solutions which have a shelf life of 2–3 weeks.)

Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is stored at −40 to −50°C, while cryoprecipitate is stored at -30°C, and both have a shelf life of one years.

questions.text: A patient with a history of esophageal varices presents with hematemesis. What is the optimal level of hemoglobin to be maintained in this patient through blood transfusions?
questions.solution:
The optimal level of Hb to be maintained, in this case, is 8 gm/dL.

The indications for blood transfusion are as follows:

  • Acute blood loss: To replace circulating volume and maintain oxygen delivery.
  • Perioperative anemia: To ensure adequate oxygen delivery during the perioperative phase.
  • Symptomatic chronic anemia: without hemorrhage or impending surgery.
Haemoglobin level (g/dL) Indications
<6 Probably will benefit from transfusion
6–8 Transfusion unlikely to be of benefit in the absence of bleeding or impending surgery
>8 No indication for transfusion in the absence of other risk factors

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient was transfused with 2 units of fresh frozen plasma following a road traffic accident. Within 2 hours of the transfusion, he became breathless and his oxygen saturation dropped to 88%. Chest X-ray showed batwing appearance. This condition occurs due to which of the following?

choices.text: Preformed IgM Ab to ABO Ag

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). The presence of antibodies against the Human Leukocyte antigen (Anti-HLA Ab) in the donor blood is implicated in the development of TRALI.

TRALI is defined as an acute lung injury that is temporally related to blood transfusion and causes non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It occurs within the first six hours following a transfusion. Screening for HLA antibodies has been introduced to prevent TRALI.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind to recipient leukocytes. The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. Testing the donor’s plasma for anti-HLA antibodies can support this diagnosis.

The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. The transfusion of plasma from male and nulliparous women donors reduces the risk of TRALI.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who is on warfarin prophylaxis for atrial fibrillation presents with massive uncontrolled haemorrhage following a fall from height. Which of the following blood components can be used for emergency reversal of warfarin therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Prothrombin Complex Concentrates (PCCs) are indicated for the emergency reversal of anticoagulant (warfarin) therapy in uncontrolled hemorrhage.

PCCs are highly purified concentrates prepared from pooled plasma. They contain factors II, IX and X. Factor VII may be included or produced separately.

Fresh frozen plasma and platelets are used in management of coagulopathy. Fresh frozen plasma is used if prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >1.5 times normal. Platelets are transfused if platelet count <50 x103/ul.

However, in the presence of non-surgical haemorrhage these tests take time to arrange and may underestimate the degree of coagulopathy.

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate is stored at a temperature of ________
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate is a supernatant precipitate of FFP (fresh frozen plasma) and is rich in factor VIII and fibrinogen.

It is stored at −30 °C and has a shelf life of two years. It is given in low fibrinogen states or factor VIII deficiency.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. Upon arrival, the patient was unconscious with blood pressure of 90/64 mmHg and a pulse rate of 139 per minute. He was immediately transfused with 4 units of packed RBCs. All of the following complications can occur in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The complication of massive transfusion includes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

The lethal triad of massive transfusion includes acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy. Other complications which can be seen in massive transfusion are:

  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency room following a motorcycle collision. On examination, the patient is drowsy and has decreased blood pressure due to bleeding from multiple injuries. 1 unit of packed RBCs has been obtained from the blood bank. What is the correct procedure for blood transfusion?

choices.text: The blood should be brought to room temperature before the transfusion
Transfusion should be started within one hour of removal from the refrigerator
Transfusion of PRBC should be completed within 4 hours
The rate of transfusion of PRBC is 50mL per hour

questions.solution:
The transfusion of packed RBCs (PRBC) should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours after the removal from the blood fridge. 

There is an increased risk of bacterial proliferation and loss of the function of blood components after they are removed from the storage temperatures. Hence, the transfusion should be started within 30 minutes of receiving the components from the blood bank. The packed RBCs should be infused at a rate of 100-150mL/hour. Warming of blood is not needed when the transfusion is at normal rates. The transfusion should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours.

questions.text: A patient with a road traffic accident presented to the emergency room and requires a large amount of fluids to be transfused. Which of the following IV cannula is preferred?
questions.solution:
Grey coloured IV cannula is required for this patient in order to transfuse large amount of fluids.

The ATLS 10th edition guidelines state that 2 cannulae of atleast 18G should be used to gain vascular access in trauma patients. In this scenario requiring large fluid transfusions, the grey (16G) cannula would be preferable to the green (18G) cannula due to the higher flow rate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA?
questions.solution:
Sepsis is defined as a “life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.” It lies in the continuous spectrum between infection and septic shock.

 qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU).

 It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),
  • high respiratory rate (≥22 breaths per min)
  • altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15).

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis.

 The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the  Sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score; which includes assessment of:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors; platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow Coma Score 
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

The SOFA score is limited by its requirement of multiple laboratory tests which makes it complex and time-consuming. In order to simplify the scoring process, the "Sepsis - 3" task force recommended the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score.

SOFA Vs qSOFA :

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system which is particulary superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. 
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment of individuals at risk for sepsis particularly useful outside the ICU. setting (i.e. ward / emergency department). However, note that it was originally designed as predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

Thereby, the best description of sepsis based on "Sepsis -3" task force recommendations would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2  Or
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

Another score that has been used is the NEWS(National Early Warning Score). It ranges from 0 to 20 and is based on respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, use of supplemental O2, temperature, systolic blood pressure, pulse rate and level of consciousness. ≥5 out of 20 is considered a positive score. 

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System (LODS) score is not recommended as it is complex and has too many variables.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: All of the following are features of SIRS except:
questions.solution:
Respiratory Rate > 20/minute or (Not and) PaCO2 < 32 mmHg (Not <35 mmHg) would be a feature of SIRS (Systemic inflammatory response syndrome).

Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is an exaggerated defense response of the body to a noxious stressor (infection, trauma, surgery, acute inflammation, ischemia, or reperfusion) to localize and then eliminate the endogenous or exogenous source of the insult.

SIRS is diagnosed when any two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (>38 Degree Celsius) or Hypothermia (<36 Degree Celsius)
  • Tachypnoea (>20/min) or PaCO2 < 32 mmHg
  • Tachycardia (>90/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/liter or <4 x 109/liter or >10% Band forms

 Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.
